\n
Coronavirus Response Information
Iberia Parish President M. Larry Richard\n
last updated April 28, 12:39 pm CDT
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12,"showEditor":false}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#2695bc","image":""},"color":"#ffffff","rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
COVID-19 is the infectious disease caused by the novel coronavirus. This new virus and disease were unknown to the population before the outbreak began in Wuhan, China, in December 2019.
This page provides information, maps and resources about the coronavirus response in our local area.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12,"showEditor":false}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#ffffff"},"rowLayout":"box","color":"#e80d0d"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Watch this page for the latest information from Iberia Parish Government
Updated Sunday, March 22, 2020:
Governor John Bel Edwards announces new Stay at Home order effective 5 pm, Monday, March 23, 2020
From Iberia Parish President M. Larry Richard
Click here for Parish President's COVID-19 communications since March 16, 2020
April 21, 2020: Letter to Governor John Bel Edwards RE: Direct Aid to Parish Government
April 15, 2020: Letters to Louisiana Congressional Delegation RE: Direct Aid to Iberia Parish Government
April 13, 2020: Public Notice Amended: A Summary of directives from the Governor and the Parish President. Citizens should follow these directives
April 1, 2020: Parish President declares curfew beginning today
April 1, 2020: Joint Press Release with St. Martin Parish President Chester Cedars
March 22, 2020: Summary of Governor's Stay at Home Order
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":6},{"component":{"name":"image-card","settings":{"src":"https://ipg.maps.arcgis.com/sharing/rest/content/items/7833aa44ae7147f2b6afd7e72b2c6b27/data","fileSrc":"","cropSrc":"","alt":"Region 4 statistics April 28, 2020","caption":"","captionAlign":"center","hyperlink":"","hyperlinkTabOption":"new","isUrl":true,"isFile":false,"state":"valid","display":{"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"reflow":false}}},"width":6}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"transparent"},"rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Iberia Parish Departmental Policy Changes due to COVID-19
Click here to view each department's policy changes. This section will change as each department's information is added. ","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"transparent"},"rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
What is the significance of the Declaration of Local Emergency?
Parish President M. Larry Richard:
Some have asked what is meant by the\nemergency declaration which I recently issued. An emergency declaration cuts\nbureaucratic delays and unifies parish government functions under the Parish\nPresident and the Iberia Parish Office of Homeland Security and Emergency\nPreparedness. This allows your Parish Government to mobilize its resources to\nrespond to a crisis. These declarations also allow us to access state and\nfederal funds that might be appropriated with respect to a particular emergency\nevent. Emergency declarations are just the first step in the process of\nreacting to an event. Recommendations for more specific action usually comes\nlater as the emergency situation, such as a storm or the Coronavirus, continues\nto develop. You will be kept informed of any recommended actions through posts\non the Iberia Parish Government website or Iberia PINS (Parish Information Notification System).","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]}]},{"containment":"fluid","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"transparent"},"rowLayout":"wide"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"social-media-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.facebook.com/IPGov","tweetAlignment":"center","tweetWidthSize":"medium","collectionType":"timeline","showHeader":true,"showBorder":true,"showBackground":true,"showFacebookPostText":true,"showTimelineTab":true,"showEventsTab":true,"showMessagesTab":true,"showCoverPhoto":true,"showLargeHeader":false}},"width":6},{"component":{"name":"iframe-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/69b726e2b82e408f89c3a54f96e8f776","height":500,"scrollable":true}},"width":6}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"transparent"},"rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"

Governor John Bel Edwards Announces Aggressive Measures to Prevent the Spread of COVID-19
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#dedcdc"},"color":"#aN","rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Local Resources","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12,"showEditor":false}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"items/gallery-card","settings":{"query":{"mode":"dynamic","num":16,"types":["dashboard","application","document","site","dataset","pageForCurrentSite"],"tags":[],"categories":[],"groups":["9662d654ac6a40af9e4dbfd1d703f413"],"catalogs":[],"ids":[],"sort":"created","access":["public"],"orgId":"ZPPrBdbq4892XaIK","siteId":"14591c74d9074cdfaf50aafb49925e1d"},"display":{"imageType":"Thumbnails","viewText":"Explore","dropShadow":"low","cornerStyle":"round","buttonType":"primary","newTab":false},"version":4}},"width":12}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#ffffff"},"rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
\n
Symptoms\n
Reported illnesses have ranged from mild symptoms to severe illness and death for confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases.
The following symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure (based on previous MERS-CoV virus incubation periods).
Source- CDC
\n\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"image-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/images/symptoms-cough.jpg","fileSrc":"","cropSrc":"","alt":"Cough with illustration of person wiping their nose","caption":"","captionAlign":"center","hyperlink":"","hyperlinkTabOption":"new","isUrl":true,"isFile":false,"state":"valid","display":{"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"reflow":false}}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"image-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/images/symptoms-fever.jpg","fileSrc":"","cropSrc":"","alt":"Fever with illustration of man sweating and holding thermometer","caption":"","captionAlign":"center","hyperlink":"","hyperlinkTabOption":"new","isUrl":true,"isFile":false,"state":"valid","display":{"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"reflow":false}}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"image-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/images/symptoms-shortness-breath.jpg","fileSrc":"","cropSrc":"","alt":"","caption":"","captionAlign":"center","hyperlink":"","hyperlinkTabOption":"new","isUrl":true,"isFile":false,"state":"valid","display":{"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"reflow":false}}},"width":4}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Call your doctor if you develop symptoms and have been in close contact with a person known to have COVID-19, or have recently traveled from an area with widespread/ongoing community spread of COVID-19.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#ffffff"},"color":"#000000","rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
What You Can Do to Prevent Illness\n\n
There is currently no vaccine to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to this virus.\n\nThe virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person:
Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).
Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.
It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":8,"showEditor":false},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Older adults and people who have severe underlying chronic medical conditions like heart or lung disease or diabetes seem to be at higher risk for developing more serious complications from COVID-19 illness.
Please consult with your health care provider about additional steps you may be able to take to protect yourself.
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Take Steps to Protect Yourself and Others","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Clean your hands often\n\n
\nWash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds especially after you have been in a public place, or after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing. If soap and water are not readily available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.\n\n\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Avoid close contact
Avoid close contact with people who are sick
Put distance between yourself and other people if COVID-19 is spreading in your community. This is especially important for people who are at higher risk of getting very sick.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Stay home if you're sick
Stay home if you are sick, except to get medical care. Learn what to do if you are sick.\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Cover coughs and sneezes
\n
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze or use the inside of your elbow.
Throw used tissues in the trash.
Immediately wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not readily available, clean your hands with a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Wear a facemask if you are sick
If you are sick: You should wear a facemask when you are around other people (e.g., sharing a room or vehicle) and before you enter a healthcare provider’s office. If you are not able to wear a facemask , then you should do your best to cover your coughs and sneezes. Learn what to do if you are sick.
If you are NOT sick: You do not need to wear a facemask unless you are caring for someone who is sick (and they are not able to wear a facemask). Facemasks may be in short supply and they should be saved for caregivers.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Clean and disinfect
Clean AND disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily. This includes tables, doorknobs, light switches, countertops, handles, desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets, and sinks.
If surfaces are dirty, clean them: Use detergent or soap and water prior to disinfection.
Complete disinfection guidance can be found here","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#dedcdc"},"rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
What to do if you are sick
See all steps from the CDC here
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":6,"showEditor":false},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Call your doctor: If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 and develop a fever and symptoms of respiratory illness, such as cough or difficulty breathing, call your healthcare provider immediately.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":6}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"\n
\n
\n
Stay Home except to get medical care\n
\n \n \n\n
\n
\n
Separate yourself from other people and animals in your home\n
\n \n \n\n
\n
\n
Call ahead before visiting a doctor\n
.\n \n \n\n
\n
\n
Cover your coughs and clean your hands often\n
\n \n \n\n
\n\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12,"showEditor":false}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#aN"},"rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
